repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
The exclusion of lists was never justified in the commit history and is
the wrong thing to do for a function that deals with tables.

Fixes #23654

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• |vim.tbl_deep_extend()| no longer ignores any values that return `true` from |vim.isarray()|.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -191,6 +191,9 @@ These existing features changed their behavior.
   top lines are calculated using screen line numbers which take virtual lines
   into account.
 
+• |vim.tbl_deep_extend()| now merges all tables regardless or contents.

comment_data.body: Duplicate code -- refactor into a local validate function?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -409,6 +398,18 @@ end
 ---@param ... table Two or more tables
 ---@return table : Merged table
 function vim.tbl_extend(behavior, ...)
+  if behavior ~= 'error' and behavior ~= 'keep' and behavior ~= 'force' then

comment_data.body: Done. And hoisted out another argument check.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -409,6 +398,18 @@ end
 ---@param ... table Two or more tables
 ---@return table : Merged table
 function vim.tbl_extend(behavior, ...)
+  if behavior ~= 'error' and behavior ~= 'keep' and behavior ~= 'force' then

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
• |vim.tbl_deep_extend()| no longer ignores any values for which |vim.isarray()| returns `true`.
```

(Sorry, only realized afterwards that it was the inverted grammar that bugged me.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -210,6 +210,9 @@ These existing features changed their behavior.
   more emoji characters than before, including those encoded with multiple
   emoji codepoints combined with ZWJ (zero width joiner) codepoints.
 
+• |vim.tbl_deep_extend()| no longer ignores any values that return `true`
+  from |vim.isarray()|.

comment_data.body: not a blocker, but... this condition doesn't seem to have a test

+  end
+
+  for i = 1, nargs do
+    vim.validate('after the second argument', select(i, ...), 'table')

@@ -395,9 +380,31 @@ local function tbl_extend(behavior, deep_extend, ...)

@@ -395,9 +380,31 @@ local function tbl_extend(behavior, deep_extend, ...)

   return ret
 end

+  if behavior ~= 'error' and behavior ~= 'keep' and behavior ~= 'force' then

comment_data.body:
Should this be moved to the BREAKING CHANGES section? For example:
```lua
vim.tbl_deep_extend('force', { levels = { true, true } }, { levels = { nil, true } })
```
returns `{ levels = { nil, true } }` before this PR and `{ levels = { true, true } }` after this PR.

An array like this is used `packer.nvim`'s (and `pckr.nvim`'s) log configuration:
```lua
  if min_active_level then
    for i = min_active_level, 6 do
      config.active_levels[i] = true
    end
  end
```
`packer.nvim` uses `vim.tbl_deep_extend()` with this table, so this PR causes its log configuration to no longer work. `pckr.nvim` doesn't use `vim.tbl_deep_extend()` with it, but its log configuration seems already broken before this PR.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -210,6 +210,9 @@ These existing features changed their behavior.
   more emoji characters than before, including those encoded with multiple
   emoji codepoints combined with ZWJ (zero width joiner) codepoints.
 
+• |vim.tbl_deep_extend()| no longer ignores any values for which |vim.isarray()|
+  returns `true`.
+

comment_data.body: I think this just exposed bugs in both of those plugins.

+• |vim.tbl_deep_extend()| no longer ignores any values for which |vim.isarray()|

+• |vim.tbl_deep_extend()| no longer ignores any values for which |vim.isarray()|
+  returns `true`.

comment_regular_data.body: needs a test?

Sure.

Also going to claim this is a perf gain since merging no longer requires scanning table elements.

EDIT: additionally, argument checks are now only done once instead of recursively.
Also refactored, so the error checks are done outside the recursive path.

seems like this would affect lazy.nvim's opts feature and many plugins which use `vim.tbl_deep_extend` to merge user configs


so here if the user wants only some items of the list, it wont work like before and now there's no way to exclude items from list, everything merges  
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3b9085e9-5d86-460c-8a6c-bbde3bc74566)

I guess all 3 distros ( lazyvim, nvchad, astro ) which use main repo + starter combination will also be affected by this and those repos which have plugin specs, like astrocommunity :thinking: 

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9d481422-cb3a-4fe1-9c4b-1714872d8362)

user has no option but to modify original table directly 

```lua
opts = function
  local default_opts = require ...
  default_opts.settings =  { abc }
  return default_opts
end
```

I would think this is most definitely a breaking change as it will break loads of plugins and people would have to pin neovim 0.10 until plugins have been fixed, 

and also what is the correct solution to merge 2 lua tables? afaik neovim only has `[deep]_extend` ? (while overriding lists)

Ok this explains why Neotest randomly stopped working for me a few days ago! I just tested and rolled back to stable core and Neotest works fine. See here: https://www.reddit.com/r/neovim/comments/1fakcly/comment/lm2q756. I suspect given timing of when it stopped working, and the timing of this PR, that this is the cause. I use lazy as a plugin manager. I know that it is preferred to not comment on PRs that are already merged, but I also don't know that this is appropriate for a new GH Issue 🤷‍♂️ 

Does @folke know about this "breaking change"? As I believe (as other comments above have stated) this could fundamentally "break" lazy from the way everyone currently uses it (whether right or wrong).

This will break **a lot** or plugins. Most plugins merge user config with their defaults and expect lists to be replaced by the user's list.

The behavior is now completely different.

This is for sure a breaking change and a big one... 

Lucklily `lazy.nvim` should be mostly fine, since I already used a custom `Util.merge` function.

```lua
local Util = require("lazy.core.util")
Util.merge(....)
```
it'd be better if we could have the old function back but named differently

> Lucklily `lazy.nvim` should be mostly fine, since I already used a custom `Util.merge` function.

@folke from your (lazy's) perspective I think a larger worry than even the actual code is the documentation and the general "understanding" for both users and plugin authors on how the `opts` replacing and merging works. The harder part (in my opinion) will be the re-evangelization of how typical Plugin defaults / config pattern works in the community, let alone dealing with plugins that are not as actively maintained. Am I right to feel this way? Or am I overthinking the impact from a community / plugin config perspective?

@GitMurf  the impact might be huge, iirc almost all plugins from v0.5 use `tbl_deep_extend` to extend user config, merge tables etc

so those which havent been updated since years wouldnt be much usable cuz of this change

The new change doesn't make a lot of sense to me to be honest.

When merging two tables, at any level, we check if both values are mergeable. I'd still argue that lists are not mergeable, in the same way that a boolean or number value is not mergeable.

The new impl now overwrites the values in the other list. Really odd. What is even the use-case for something like that?
Comparing to javascript, deep merging objects (like with lodash, ramda, ...) also works like how `tbl_deep_extend` used to work.

> The new impl now overwrites the values in the other list. Really odd. What is even the use-case for something like that?

**EDIT:** see clarification Folke made below and my follow-up below.

~~I believe it is the opposite. Before if you had `{ some_opt = { 'lua', 'markdown', 'rust' }` and then you tried to replace the option / list (like overriding a plugin default config) with `{ some_opt = { 'typescript', 'javascript' }` then you will end up with a merge of all the array/list items which means you will have `{ some_opt = { 'lua', 'markdown', 'rust', 'typescript', 'javascript' }`. The problem being that now you are stuck with whatever the plugin dev default options are. I cannot override / remove 'lua', 'markdown', 'rust' from the config option. I can only ADD to it.~~

~~@siduck is this what you understand as well?~~

No, you'll end up with `typescript, javascript, rust`.

Before, you'd end up with the new list, so `typescript, javascript`

The new `tbl_deep_extend` does not **extend** lists, but it overwrites the same indices in the original list.

This makes **zero** sense.

~~As I understand with the new change the behavior is as follows: `table_a.concat(table_b).unique()` ?~~

Edit: okay I understood now and yeah, it's very unintuitive
Nope, see my updated comment above.

> No, you'll end up with `typescript, javascript, rust`.
> 
> Before, you'd end up with the new list, so `typescript, javascript`

OH wow! So I agree @folke ... that is even "less intuitive" in my opinion! Is the idea that it is treating a list with indexes of [1], [2], [3] as if they were table keys like "foo", "bar" and "baz" so then the "ordering" of the array/list items matters as well? This almost feels like it is treating Lists like Tuples in a way?

**EDIT:** meaning if list_1 has { "one", "two", "three" } and list_2 has { "four" } then you end up with { "four", "two", "three" } so the original "index position" (ordering) of list_1 matters because the first items will be replaced by list_2 items first.

@GitMurf yep, exactly like that. `{"a", "b", "c"}` in lua is the same as `{[1] = "a", [2] = "b", [3] = "c"}`.

The new `tbl_deep_extend` function now also treats it literally like that, so the exact indices will be overwritten.

Again, `ramda, lodash` and all other libraries I know of in javascript work how `tbl_deep_extend` used to work.

The new impl, is just weird. Will be a mess to document.

Edit: also yep to your edit
I wish the commit to be reverted!
There's too much noise here. The relevant points have already been made (multiple times), and adding "me too" and "I can't believe you did this!111!" comments just make them harder to follow.

Well, the current docstring for `tbl_deep_extend` is completely insufficient. It needs to explain why it is called "deep extend" yet ignores certain kinds of tables (if we restore the old behavior). And it needs to show a small example and mention the use-case.

There are many mentions about javascript here but js has a very different typesystem, with completely distinct map-like objects and _real_ arrays. It is not to be expected that a function labeled "tbl" should emulate js-specific expectations rather than native lua tables (where there is just keys, some of which are integers). 

However the JS/JSON data model is a foreign typesystem we _do_ support as such (because of LSP, and other good reasons), so something like `vim.tbl_extend_jsonlike` (or a "jsonlike" flag in an options table) would make good sense.

repo.name: neovim

title: fix(lua): allows tables with integer keys to be merged in tbl_deep_extend
